Obviously there's the "Number forty-seven said to number three" verse, but isn't the title a euphemism for shagging. Also, "The Purple Gang" were sex cases either, rapists, peadohiles or homosexuals (1950âs, hey) but someone state side can confirm or shoot this down. 

Aynone know what "The sad sack" is?

comment_10:
Elvis was gay.

Not quite true, but I thought my first post should be controvertial in some way. This song does contain a bit of homosexual inuendo however,

"Number forty-seven said to number three: 
You're the cutest jailbird I ever did see. 
I sure would be delighted with your company, 
come on and do the Jailhouse Rock with me. "

A bit of a joke I think.

comment_13:
There could of been a girl inmate. Lol. I think it was a kinda of joke by the writers. If say a little kid asked "Why did he say that guy was cute?" There parents could say "......It was girl." This was the '50's anyway and nobody was gay. At least they didn't tell anybody. Anyway..........

The band the Purple Gang ("Granny Takes A Trip") got their name from this song. And if you want a GREAT cover of this check out The Residents' version. It's definitely different.

comment_16: Presley sang it as straight hard rock, there are parts of the Leiber and Stoller lyrics that represent talk about same-sex relationships between inmates. For instance: "Number forty-seven said to number /… the cutest jailbird I ever did see./I sure would be delighted with your company,/Come on and do the jailhouse rock with me." However, many see this as a lighthearted reference to forced environmental improvisation.

comment_21:
The Purple Gang ran the streets of Detroit during the 1920's & 1930's when alcohol was illegal. The Purple Gang was feared by other gangsters, they were killers; they ran all the alcohol blind pigs & speakeasys, as well as all the prostitution and drugs. 
Detroit, being across the river from Canada, was a quick route to bring in illegal alcoholin America by boat. 
The Purple Gang even provided illegal alcohol to Al Capone's gang & other well known gangs. 
Also, the Detroit Jails housed females & males near each other until after Sentencing, then the females & males were sent to separate male/female housing. The song did referred attraction between a male and female, most likely a prostitute. 
I'm grew up with all the first hand stories from Grandparents involved in both the legal & illegal parts of Detroit history.
